hero.originalTitle: Green energy sector drove more than 90% of China's investment growth last year, analysis finds
hero.headline: China's Green Machine: Clean Energy Powers Economic Growth Like Never Before
hero.excerpt: China's clean energy industries drove more than 90% of the country's investment growth last year, making the sectors bigger than all but seven of the world's economies. For the second time in three years, the manufacture, installation and export of batteries, electric cars, solar, wind and related technologies accounted for more than a third of China's economic growth.
hero.author: Gusty Winds

fullContent.lead: What happens when a country decides to go all-in on the future? China just gave us a pretty spectacular answer, with their green energy sector powering more than 90% of the nation's investment growth last year.
body: Let's put this in perspective: China's clean energy industries have grown so massive that they're now bigger than all but seven of the world's entire economies. We're talking about a sector that encompasses everything from batteries and electric cars to solar panels and wind turbines – and it's absolutely booming.

This green revolution isn't just a one-hit wonder either. For the second time in three years, the manufacture, installation, and export of these clean technologies accounted for more than a third of China's total economic growth. That's like having your renewable energy sector become the main character in your country's economic story.

What makes this particularly exciting is the ripple effect. When one of the world's largest economies makes this kind of commitment to clean technology, it doesn't just benefit them – it drives innovation, brings costs down globally, and creates momentum for the entire planet's transition to cleaner energy. It's the kind of economic shift that could power positive change far beyond China's borders.

factCheck.summary: All key facts and statistics from the original source are accurately represented in the generated article. featured.originalTitle: Wind farms provided a third of Ireland's electricity in record 2025 but 13pc went to waste

featured.excerpt: Wind farms provided a third of Ireland's electricity in a record-breaking 2025. The increased wind energy production helped push down wholesale electricity prices from €136.99 per megawatt hour in December 2024 to €108.48 per megawatt hour in December 2025.

fullContent.lead: Ireland just had its windiest year on record – and we mean that in the best possible way. Wind farms generated a full third of the country's electricity in 2025, marking a historic milestone for renewable energy on the Emerald Isle.
body: This renewable energy surge wasn't just good for the planet – it was good for people's wallets too. The increased wind power helped drive down wholesale electricity prices significantly, dropping from €136.99 per megawatt hour in December 2024 to €108.48 per megawatt hour by December 2025.

That's the kind of price drop that makes everyone do a little happy dance, especially when it comes from clean, renewable sources. Wind energy has been steadily growing across Ireland, and 2025 proved to be the breakthrough year that showed just how powerful those turbines can be when Mother Nature cooperates.

While the report notes that 13% of the wind energy generated went to waste, the overall picture remains impressively bright. Hitting the one-third mark for wind-generated electricity represents a major step forward in Ireland's renewable energy journey – and a sign that clean power is becoming increasingly central to keeping the lights on across the country.

issues: Article claims '2025' as a completed year when the source appears to be reporting on 2025 data while still in 2025

fullContent.lead: What if we told you that humanity just took another giant leap backward in time? NASA's James Webb Space Telescope has spotted a galaxy that's been shining bright since the universe was practically a toddler—just 280 million years after the Big Bang.

The newly confirmed galaxy pushes our view of the observable universe closer to the very beginning than we've ever managed before. To put that in perspective, this galaxy was already up and running when the universe was barely out of its cosmic diapers.

The previous record holder was a galaxy spotted 300 million years after the Big Bang, which means our new stellar superstar beat that milestone by a solid 20 million years. In cosmic terms, that's like finding baby photos from before you thought cameras were even invented.

What makes this discovery so thrilling isn't just the 'wow, that's old' factor—though that's certainly part of it. This galaxy's existence tells us that the universe was getting busy forming complex structures much earlier than we previously thought possible. It's like discovering that your great-great-great-grandmother was already running a successful business when everyone assumed she was still learning to walk.

Thanks to the James Webb Space Telescope's incredible capabilities, we're literally seeing further back in time than ever before, watching the universe's early chapters unfold in real time. And if history is any guide, this record won't hold forever—which means even more amazing discoveries are likely headed our way.

fullContent.lead: Picture the world's third-largest cat—a 300-pound apex predator that could make short work of just about anything in its path. Now imagine that same magnificent beast calling out with the exact same sound your tabby makes when demanding breakfast. Thanks to recent camera trap footage, we now know that's exactly what happens when jaguars are searching for their cubs.

These massive felines, despite their impressive size and fearsome reputation, sound remarkably similar to the house cats we know and love when they're calling for their young.

The breakthrough came through camera trap technology, which finally managed to document this previously unrecorded behavior. While we've long known that domestic cats meow primarily to communicate with humans (they mostly use other vocalizations with each other), it turns out their wild cousins have kept this particular sound in their repertoire for family matters.

It's one of those delightful reminders that no matter how different species might seem on the surface, there are often surprising connections hiding underneath. A jaguar may be built like a living tank and capable of taking down caimans, but when it comes to calling the kids home for dinner, apparently the universal cat language kicks in.

But they're not just art enthusiasts – they're dedicated to wildlife conservation too. By connecting their passion for Rembrandt's artistic genius with their commitment to protecting the majestic creatures he captured on paper, they've created something pretty magical: a bridge between 400-year-old art and modern conservation efforts.

It's the kind of story that reminds you how art can inspire action across centuries. This discovery is particularly exciting because it sheds new light on the Zapotec people, whose rich cultural heritage often gets overshadowed by their more famous Mayan neighbors. This remarkable discovery demonstrates the incredible resilience of life in the most extreme conditions imaginable. We're talking about a vacuum that would instantly kill most living things, yet these spores held on like the ultimate cosmic survivors they apparently are.

fullContent.lead: Deep beneath our feet, two massive hot rock structures have been working the night shift for millions of years, quietly choreographing one of Earth's most vital features. While we often think of our planet as constantly changing, these findings suggest there are some deep, fundamental structures that have been keeping things steady for eons.

This isn't just academic curiosity—understanding how our magnetic field works and what influences it helps scientists better predict its future behavior. Our magnetic field is what keeps us from getting fried by solar particles, so having these ancient guardians working behind the scenes is definitely something worth celebrating. Sometimes the most important work happens where no one can see it, and apparently that includes the very center of our planet.
